body: This is a known issue with SQL, not related to this pull request. The gradle setup does some kind of `find . -name '*.java'` at a moment when a generated file is found. Then it saves that source set but the file is not found later.
run java gradle precommit

I want to confirm whether or not something about this change makes the flake worse, so it will slow down other development. But I'm ambivalent about holding up work on known flakes in Gradle build. Probably we should sickbay aspects of the SQL gradle build instead.
Green!
run java gradle precommit
Looked like flakes in IOs but only on gradle build.
retest this please
Tests passed.
Awesome...  don't need to keep rebasing and fixing things!   :)

r: @kennknowles 
getting another reviewer

Any conclusions here?

On Wed, Jan 31, 2018 at 1:26 PM, Reuven Lax <relax@google.com> wrote:

> The problem with Record is that we already refer to all elements in the
> Beam model as "records."
>
> On Wed, Jan 31, 2018 at 1:21 PM, Robert Bradshaw <notifications@github.com
> > wrote:
>
>> Having dealt with this before (actually, I think it was literally a Row
>> class) I can say that having to fully qualify names is painful in Java. One
>> workaround is to put it in a nested class, such that it can be imported as
>> just Row or used with a (shorter) qualification as needed. My preference
>> would be to just keep the Beam prefix on the class itself. My $0.02, not
>> held to strongly.
>>
>> As for Record -> Row, I was an instigator of the original name Record to
>> try to denote that this wasn't bound to SQL alone (though my biggest
>> concern was pulling it up to a top-level Beam value rather than keeping it
>> in the SQL namespace). I think of a Record as an element with fields, which
>> is what is being specified here. But again, if Row makes more sense to
>> folks, that's fine by me.
>>
>> —
>> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
>> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
>> <https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4550#issuecomment-362074761>, or mute
>> the thread
>> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AUGE1T8cNb6g67cj9jsYIyTwMkvO7nYDks5tQNl2gaJpZM4R0h6j>
>> .
>>
>
>

It seems for most, if not all, of these uses of xrange, range would be perfectly acceptable as well (i.e. the ranges in question are quite small). Could you change these to use the vanilla range rather than import xrange from six?
Thank you for the catch!

The lifetime of Python 2 is now just two years long.  An alternative (probably safer) approach would be to leave this PRs as written until 2020 and then dropping Python 2 support will only require 1) removing the import and 2) doing a global find-and-replace of 'xrange(' --> 'range('.

I am willing to go whichever way you feel is best.
Unless there is a compelling reason to use xrange over range for any of these in Python 2 (I don't see one), let's change to range now.

I'm -0 on the move from Record to Row, -0.5 on dropping the Beam prefix,
and +1 on getting this in without a huge amount of bikeshedding.

> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4550#issuecomment-362392202>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAdqgQDVcQrnsoIkbkxo5FtI-SQbwHrVks5tQh7RgaJpZM4R0h6j>
> .

The thing I like about Row vs Record (in addition to being easier to type :-) is that it carries with it an implication of there being columns somewhere. So as we add more columnar support directly into Beam (regardless of whether SQL is in play or not), the Row name would provide a little hint that there are columnar things lurking around as well.

For me, Row > Record > BeamRow > BeamRecord. But I don't feel super strongly, and will live with BeamRecord if we just stick with that. So big +1 to not bikeshedding to death.

Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
We should assume every object is non-null, and put the findbugs `DefaultAnnotation` on the package. (separately from this PR)
done --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamAggregationRel.java, line 132 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4EdXpXI9r0vQU5sTA6:-L4EnRtO5AF4f56gJla1:bu18h98) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamAggregationRel.java#L132)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
We should go farther than this, perhaps. You don't have to do it in this PR, but maybe file a ticket. I believe we can also analyze some other triggers that are not meaningful. Or you could argue that if the user sets it themselves then we should respect their request to never have output...
We can look into that. Filed [BEAM-3588](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3588). It's fine to handle only defaults here because it's the same check as in GBK, we're just providing more context in the exception. If new validations are added to basic PTransofrms, then in the worst case SQL will expose those without wrapping. My main concern about performing more complex validation is that I'm not sure that we can solve it in general case (or even limited case). And without it it can become confusing if you can define 2 equivalent triggers and one will be rejected while the other will not. --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamAggregationRel.java, line 158 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4Ecx-pQb4v_ecbhmEl:-L4EtNcwNzj5e1aeAhhz:b-tw1l6x) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamAggregationRel.java#L158)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
This one seems a bit silly
Inlined these :) I wrote the invocations first to make sure`if` looks sane, and then implementations just ended up this way :) Should have just copied the GBK version from the start --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowFactory.java, line 40 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4EbkphEoAj2-gp5rhM:-L4FISdCztxez_DMCMoh:bq4wpo1) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowFactory.java#L40)):*

Are you sure the Calcite and Beam chose the same reference point for the offset?
discussed offline, this seems correct --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowField.java, line 36 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4EbMw3L0Jx0E4saRhv:-L4EvkUyZJ91drVArRXQ:b-nmdh20) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowField.java#L36)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Now that we are on Java 8, you can use `Optional` anywhere that it is not a known problem allocating too many wrappers. Not sure how much they are optimized away to behave as well as nullables but I would use them by default until you find a problem.
Wrapped the whole `AggregateWindowField` into `Optional`. My impression was that using `java.util.Optional` in class fields is discouraged (e.g. `java.util.Optional` is not serializable), so I thought that domain-specific logic would be better, and it just happens to have similar semantics with `Maybe`. It could have more state and logic, in my case it probably saved an `Optional.map()`call when extracting `windowFieldIndex`. Don't have a strong opinion in this case. --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowField.java, line 51 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4EbCFdCRLQt5NszKRb:-L4FIIwsVaLKY788H2Jx:bb7f2mf) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowField.java#L51)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Now that we are on Java 8, you could use `Optional` to decouple the data you want to store from the present/absent.

Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
This is minor, but when I skimmed this I saw the `assertEquals` below and the declaration of `input` above and thought the test was wrong. There's no perf benefit to reassigning here, so use another variable for clarity.
done --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamSqlDslAggregationTest.java, line 475 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4EeHtXE6dYlev2lAwH:-L4F-CU-SJiSeyMPs-1I:b-fzcjgm) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamSqlDslAggregationTest.java#L475)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
To be honest, I don't really care that much about equality of continuation trigger. What this confirms is that there was one GBK and the trigger wasn't rewritten, which is fine. What is better to test would actually be outputs. You could use `TestStream` to provide interesting inputs to the SQL and then `PAssert` to check what comes out in each window.
I agree, updated the tests to validate results --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamSqlDslBase.java, line 46 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4Eegdri7czMoGIRDkG:-L4EyKoHrby2Tu4_TOLH:b-rsc81d) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamSqlDslBase.java#L46)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
This class seems like generally a bad idea. Tests are almost always read one at a time, and should essentially be just read in a straight line. It is the opposite of usual software engineering - reuse makes them less maintainable.
I agree. This class has only 5 subclasses, should be easy to refactor. There are similar classes `BeamSqlBuiltinFunctionsIntegrationTestBase` with 7 and `BeamSqlFnExecutorTestBase` with 24. Probably there are others. I'd prefer to do this in another PR :) --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546)*

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowFactory.java, line 116 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4JPNCJzuq1qkTBBJiB:-L4JPNCJzuq1qkTBBJiC:b2nh4j5) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/ecd89b856ffd85baa769ecbe27615ffaf79f2195/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowFactory.java#L116)):* > ```Java > > SlidingWindows slidingWindows = SlidingWindows > .of(durationParameter(parameters, 2)) > ``` :-) --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowField.java, line 36 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-L4EbMw3L0Jx0E4saRhv:-L4JPbZzQUY-VEGDM0bf:b-833xbc) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/33eeedfeae4d7534265f237549ff9eb4b5f3d58f/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rule/AggregateWindowField.java#L36)):*
Previously, akedin (Anton Kedin) wrote…
Wrapped the whole `AggregateWindowField` into `Optional`. My impression was that using `java.util.Optional` in class fields is discouraged (e.g. `java.util.Optional` is not serializable), so I thought that domain-specific logic would be better, and it just happens to have similar semantics with `Maybe`. It could have more state and logic, in my case it probably saved an `Optional.map()`call when extracting `windowFieldIndex`. Don't have a strong opinion in this case.
Wow, didn't realize the `Optional` was not serializable. Found https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24547673/why-java-util-optional-is-not-serializable-how-to-serialize-the-object-with-suc Pretty arrogant for them to speak as though they were "designing" `Optional` since it predates even the first version of Java (same with generics, so I guess there's a pattern). And pretty annoying for them to take a purist stance, since Java is a pragmatic compromise language. This `Serializable` issue is a good argument for not including it in fields. And since that is a stupid thing to have to remember, we might just want to ban it (pretty easy to use static analysis to ban classes) and go back to using Guava's `Optional` or rolling our own. Sheesh. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4546#-:-L4J_yNoGn4Z-sF51pD7:b-ikyoki)*

BTW I'm working on the same thing to get a proper import to IntelliJ. I had success adding the directory both as a `sourceDir` and a `generatedSourceDir`: https://github.com/kennknowles/beam/commits/intellij

It seems to work OK but it is clear that one of our plugins is thrashing intellij by constantly dropping a lot of files somewhere that is causing reindex
... when I say "work OK" I mean that is solved that problem but by no means actually allows a clean import. I'm going to put slightly more effort into reproducing a "works the first time" import.

retest this please

+1 to keep the Beam prefix, I would take the *duplication* so users are clear that it's related with Beam, there're so many classes named as Row. 
either BeamRow or BeamRecord is good to me.

A pull request isn't really the right place for a vote, but here's the tally, if we accept half votes:

`BeamRow`: 2.5 @XuMingmin @reuvenlax  @robertwb (half)
`Row`: 2.5 @takidau @akedin @kennknowles (half)

So that is perfectly unhelpful :-)

I should clarify: the build always "succeeds" when delegated to Gradle. That isn't terribly helpful for actually getting work done. You need IntelliJ's UI to know about everything. This solves it for proto.

Weirdly, the import was quick and easy on OSX but initial build seems to drag on to tens of minutes on Linux. Could be an internal Google thing.

I have resolved the issues with the Dataflow runner, opting to leave those URNs currently hard coded in the workers as they are in this PR (which is already big and painful enough as it is) and defer the worker dance to a future one.

PTAL

Run Java JdbcIO Performance Test
OK - now SQL seems happy too.
+1 to Row

Looks like those builds are grabbing an older snapshot of the build-tools jar and they don't build that themselves.   Now that a new snapshot is deployed, they should be OK providing the build is setup to update snapshots.

I just did a couple queries in the public GitHub data set and there's Hive and Cassandra and SparkSQL. Basically everyone who has a row calls it that. I think everyone does this because it is best for their users, even if implementing becomes uglier for a couple files. Changing to +1 full support for just `Row` actually.

I'm convinced, and at this point most people seem to be leaning to Row. Ken
pointed out that most other systems (Hive, Cassandra, Spark, etc.) just use
Row. Since there was discussion, we should send a note to the dev list
about this.

For now I've changed the class name to be Row.
